title: Optical Form and Function of Leafhopper-Produced Brochosomes
content: Leafhoppers excrete brochosomes and apply them over their body surfaces as deployable materials. These leafhopper-produced brochosomes are hollow, three-dimensional, buckyball-shaped nanoscopic granules featuring distributed nanoscale through-holes. These structures represent a novel class of biologically inspired optical materials, with demonstrated functionality in omnidirectional antireflection [1, 2]. Despite their discovery in the 1950s, it remains unknown how the dimensions and geometry of brochosomes are related to their optical function [3]. In this invited talk, I will explore how the distinct geometry of brochosomes contributes to their unique optical function and further discuss their potential applications in optical signature management, including antireflection and information encryption [2-5].
